oai_dc:dc.dc:title: An appeal to the Governor and people of Tennessee (1946)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: An appeal written by Clark Foreman who was the President of the Southern Conference for Human Welfare for the fair treatment of the African Americans involved in the Columbia Race Riots.

The Southern Conference for Human Welfare was an Alabama based organization that was committed to improving social justice and civil rights between the years 1938-1948. Clark Foreman was a civil rights activist who was strongly affected by a lynching he witnessed at age 17. He served as an advisor on Southern policy during the Roosevelt Administration, was the founder and president of the Southern Conference for Human Welfare, and was the director of the Emergency Civil Liberties Committee from the years 1951-1968.
